description: The EU hopes its border pricing scheme will drive stronger climate action abroad. Read more at straitstimes.com.
title: EU carbon border tariff unpopular, but needed
title_page: EU carbon border tariff unpopular, but needed | The Straits Times
maintext:
On Oct 1, the European Union launched one of its most ambitious climate policies yet. It began the pilot phase of a scheme that will tax carbon-intensive goods imported from outside the bloc. The Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) focuses on imports that have a significant carbon footprint from their production.
The EU is doing this because many industries, from steel- and cement-making to power generation and fertiliser production, are big polluters, whose emissions are driving climate change.
